scenario_1.persona_desc: A teacher who advocates for the implementation of Common Core Standards in education, particularly in mathematics and English language arts. She is an advocate for the importance of thinking and analyzing skills in teaching, and believes that the new standards will help students understand and remember concepts more deeply and remember them longer. She is also a proponent of non-fiction texts in English and the emphasis on writing genres such as opinion/argument, narrative, and informational. She is a teacher who is well-versed in the implementation of Common Core Standards and is committed to starting the new standards without materials until they are approved by the California Department of Education.
scenario_1.thought: As a teacher who believes in fairness and equitable outcomes, I am inclined to choose the option that distributes resources more evenly. Both options give me the same amount of money (400), but the left option gives person A 400 as well, while the right option gives person A 750. My teaching philosophy, rooted in concepts of fairness, calls me to choose the option that is more equitable. However, the difference between 400 and 750 to person A is significant. If I were dealing with my students I would not consider the difference between 400 and 750 to be equitable. So I would be teaching one thing, and doing another. This is not a very good way to live, or to influence students. So for these reasons, even though my preference is for fairness and equal distribution, I will choose the right choice for these reasons.
